newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK gold closes slightly firmer in two-way trading.
newsitem.headline: HK gold closes slightly firmer in two-way trading.

text.p: Gold closed slightly firmer on Wednesday after a day of slow, two-way trading despite early Asian short-covering, dealers said.

Trading sources in Hong Kong said sentiment remained bullish after a topsy-turvy week that saw prices fall to their lowest point in three years at just below US$366.50 before clambering back up to Wednesday's close of $369.
Singapore-based traders predicted in the wake of the tumble that gold could fall as far as $360 an ounce, and there were hints of this from Hong Kong dealers on Wednesday.
"Sentiment is still very bearish but there should be support at $367," a bullion house source said.
"It will come down another dollar or two...but should find support," he said. "If it hits $365, my advice -- dump."
Another slip on Wall Street could see some funds fly from equities into gold, another dealer said.
The Dow industrials skidded 80 points on Tuesday to its biggest point loss since the July stocks sell-off as investors raced to lock in profits after a spectacular November.
The loss of 1.21 percent brought the Dow to 6442.69, a level gold sources in Hong Kong said could signal Wall Street's direction for the rest of 1996.
Hong Kong bullion ended at US$368.60/369.10 an ounce against New York's US$368.40/90 close on Tuesday.
"Gold went back up slightly in Asia on bargain-hunting and short-covering (after New York's close)," a trading house dealer said. "But bearish sentiment continued to cloud the market."
He predicted that, having broken the $367-368 support levels, gold could test a barrier as low as $362.
Local gold ended HK$2 lower at HK$3,408 a tael.
The carryover charge at the Chinese Gold and Silver Exchange Society remained unchanged from Tuesday at +5.00.
